Dry reforming of methane, in which harmful greenhouse gases convert to syngas, is one of the most important approaches to reducing concerns about global warming and increasing greenhouse gases. It was well found that support has a key role in the catalytic performance of heterogeneous catalysts in all aspects of chemistry. In this study, the effect of mullite(3Al2O3·2SiO2) ceramics as a support for the immobilization of Ni and Co to prepare bimetallic catalyst was explored in dry reforming of methane (DRM) at a temperature range of 650–800°C and gas hour space velocity (GHSV) equal to 15000 ml g⁻¹ h⁻¹. To evaluate the synergetic effect of the Ni-Co alloy, the diverse range of Ni/Co mass ratios (1:0, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 0:1) were prepared via the co-impregnation method. The synthesized materials were characterized through X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption/desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), dot mapping analysis, Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS), Dynamic light scattering (DLS), temperature-programmed reduction analysis (H2-TPR), H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Based on findings, the mullite support has the high potential to act as appropriate support to immobilize metal particles with good distribution, which is beneficial for BR, especially in terms of coke and sintering resistivity. Among synthesized catalysts, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite showed the highest CH4, CO2 conversions, and H2 yield at 800°C. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biogas reforming Mullite support Bimetallic catalyst CO2 conversion H2 production Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction In light of the constant rise in energy demand and the negative effect of fossil fuels on the environment, the quest for alternative energy supplies has become continuously important [1–3]. Therefore, much attention is devoted to a flexible renewable energy source, that is biogas. In fact, the importance and significant place of biogas stem from its high ability to substitute fossil fuels. Carbon dioxide and methane are the major components of biogas, with a small amount of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and ammonia (NH3) [4,5]. Biogas is produced by the anaerobic or bacterial digestion of biomass which comes from organic waste that has been collected from sewage, sludge, landfills, and industries [2,6–9]. However, the composition and CH4/CO2 ratio vary depending on the feedstock and digestive process [8]. Overall, the biogas reforming (BR) reactions involved in dry reforming of methane (DRM) (Eq. (1)) and reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) (Eq. (2)) reactions as shown below [1]. (1) CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2H2 + 2CO, ΔH298K= 247 kJ/mol (2) CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O, ΔH298K= 41 kJ/mol BR can be used to convert high-value synthesis gas (a mixture of CO and H2), which contains a significant amount of carbon dioxide (45%–75%) and carbon monoxide (55%–75%), without need for the costly process of separating CO2 from CH4 and releasing it into the environment. Syngas, on the other hand, is an essential step in the production of hydrogen, ammonia, methanol, and synthetic hydrocarbon fuels. Therefore, after dry reforming biogas to syngas, the Fischer-Tropsch process may create liquid biofuels in the desired range (gasoline, diesel, or jet) [10–13]. However, there are two severe difficulties associated with DRB. Methane dry reforming is a highly endothermic process that occurs at high temperatures (800-1000°C) and lower pressures. According to Eqs. (3)–(5), carbon deposition (Boudouard reaction (BR)) (Eq. (3)), methane decomposition (MD) (Eq. (4)), and carbon monoxide reduction (Eq. (5)) may easily develop at very high temperatures, blocking the active sites of the catalyst and lowering their activity drastically [14–16]. High temperatures and low pressures promote endothermic MD reaction, and also higher pressure and lower temperatures encourage the exothermic Boudouard reaction. (3) 2CO ↔ C + CO2, ΔH298K= -171 kJ/mol (4) CH4 ↔ C + H2, ΔH298K= 75 kJ/mol (5) CO+H2 ↔ C + H2O, ΔH298K= -131 kJ/mol The coke formation is a major issue with the biogas reforming, which acts as an obstacle toward its commercialization. The reaction temperature, reactant flow rate, catalyst support, and active phase may all be modified to improve catalyst stability and resistance to carbon deposition [17,18]. Thus, many efforts have been focused on designing catalysts with low carbon deposition in order to reduce the rate of coke formation [19–23]. On the other hand, due to conducting BR at high temperatures, the thermal and chemical stability of support has a key and vital role in successfully progressing the reaction. To date, various supports have been used, and promising results have been obtained [24,25], but there is still great room to expand it to improve the results of biogas reforming reaction results. In this context, natural nanoclays have also been used by various scientific groups and their catalytic performance has been evaluated in BR [26,27]. Mullite with the stoichiometric composition of (3Al2O3.2SiO2) and edge-shaped AlO6 octahedral chains in the c-axis that are cross-linked by corner-shared (Si, Al)O4 tetrahedral has the most stable phase in the Al2O3-SiO2 phase diagram [28–32]. Moreover, the Al-O and Si-O tetrahedra double chains with Al and Si atoms join the warp chains in the crystal structure [33]. These features resulted in mullite possessing high-temperature structural, chemical, and thermal stability, low conductivity, good fracture toughness, and a low coefficient of thermal expansion [29,33–35]. Inspired by these promising features of mullite ceramics, up until now, numerous research on the usage of mullite in different aspects of chemistry has been reported [36–39]. In recent years, the development of a range of noble and transition-metal-supported catalysts for DRM or BR has been the focus of much work [40]. Co and Ni-based catalysts are the most desirable combination of transition metals for DRB reaction due to their high activity, selectivity, and cheap cost. Moreover, they exhibit strong intrinsic activity, which is particularly noticeable when the Co and Ni are widely spread on the support [41–46]. On the other hand, these catalysts could become less effective throughout the catalytic process due to carbon deposition and sintering processes [18,46]. Recently, the effect of halloysite nanoclay as a support for the immobilization of bimetallic Ni-Co alloy was investigated. The prepared catalysts showed good performance and coke resistance for biogas reforming reaction catalysts owing to transferring electrons from cobalt which inhibits the oxidation of Ni [45]. In another report, Zhu and co-workers [47] synthesized a series of Ni, CoO-supported halloysite nanotubes and evaluated their application in the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol. Gao et al. [48] described that Co could create a high electron density around Ni which kept Ni from getting oxidized and building up during the synthesizing of a Ni-Co/SiO2 catalyst. Herein, in continuation of our interest in synthesizing catalysts for BR [49,50], we investigated the performance of mullite ceramics as a support for the immobilization of the Ni-Co bimetallic system in biogas reforming reaction. We speculated that it could be considered promising support due to its high-temperature structural stability and strength toward decomposition. Furthermore, the catalytic effect of cobalt in biogas methane reforming reaction has been examined and explored with a set of reaction and characterization techniques. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information All chemical materials used in the research were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Mullite as a carrier (3Al2O3.2SiO2 99%, -325 Mesh Powder Thermo Fisher Scientific) was purchased from Alfa Aesar company, Cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co (NO₃)₂·6H₂O, 99% Merck), Nikel (II) nitrate hexahydrate(Ni(NO₃)₂.6H₂O, 99% Merck), and deionized (DW). To report the mullite phase purity and structure of synthesized samples, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of all the samples were undertaken on a Bruker D8 Advance Germany power X-ray diffractometer via cu kα monochromatized radiation source. Data were extracted in the range of 2θ=10–80° with an angular step size of 0.05° degree and long counting times to obtain the position of the peaks of each sample. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of the catalysts was characterized via nitrogen adsorption/desorption at 77 K and in the p/p0 range between 0.009 and 0.98 by utilizing ASPA-2020 analyzer apparatus in static mode. Prior to characterization, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 573 K for more than 10 h. The pore volume and pore size distribution were calculated by Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were captured via VEGAII, TESCAN instrument, to observe the surface morphology and crystalline structure of the samples. The FESEM was put to use in order to investigate the microstructure and morphology of the base materials, as well as the welding interface, and to analyze the changes in grain size throughout the joint. To explore the connection between microstructure and mechanical qualities, it is necessary to conduct research on the microstructure of the welding zone. Additionally, dot mapping analysis was used to assess the dispersion and demonstrate the presence of metals. Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) was carried out using HITACHI S-4160 instrument to investigate the elemental composition of prepared catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) gives the formation of the layers, their makeup, and flaws in semiconductors, crystal structure, structural details, and metal dispersion. An automatic device (Quantachrome, TPD/TPR 3000-ChemBET) that was outfitted with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to perform a temperature-programmed reduction analysis (H2-TPR) in order to evaluate the reduction capability of the elaborated catalysts. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using the flow of air to heat the samples from 25 to 800°C with a heating rate of 20°C min−1 for evaluating the thermal stability and amount of coke deposition. Dynamic light scattering (DLS) analysis was performed using a Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern Instruments). Samples were processed through H2 pulse temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) on the Chem BET Pulsar with using the Micromeritics 2900 equipment via thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To evaluate the metal dispersion on catalysts, H2-Pulse chemisorption was carried out on 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite. According to the results of the H2-TPR, the samples were reduced with 5 vol% H2/Ar mixed gas (30 mL/min) for 1 h at various temperatures. After reduction, pure Ar was injected, and the catalyst samples were cooled down to around 25°C. Then the H2-pulse was injected (until the peak area detected by the TCD detector remained the same. The metal dispersions of Co and Ni were calculated by assuming the stoichiometry of H to surface of Ni or Co was 1. After H2-pulse, H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was performed from around 50°C to 850°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min with Ar. 2.2 Preparation of Ni-Co/mullite catalysts All the samples were prepared by following the one or two-step incipient-wetness impregnation method. To this end, different ratios of Ni/Co = 0.5, 1, and 2 with fixed Ni+Co mass ratios of 20 wt.% as well as 20 wt.% Ni and 20 wt.% Co were synthesized. Initially, a specified amount of support was sonicated for 30 min. Then, Co and Ni aqueous solutions were prepared separately and added dropwise distinctly by laboratory burette to the dispersed mullite support suspension for 1 h. Subsequently, the samples were dried at 373 K for 12 h and calcined with 3 K/min ratio at 1073 K for 4 under static air. The synthesized catalysts are labeled as xNi-yCo/mullite as in the text, in which x= Ni wt.% and y= Co wt.%. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements of biogas methane reforming The evaluations of catalytic activity were carried out in a quartz-made tube continuous reactor with the dimensions of 700 mm,9 mm, and 2 mm in length, inner diameter, and thickness, respectively. In order to maintain a consistent and high temperature, the reactor had an electric furnace. Catalyst particles was located in the center of the reactor, which was covered by a porous plate. 0.25 g of catalyst particles were placed into the reactor. The reaction conditions were 650, 700, 750, 800°C, 30 mL/min methane flow rate, and 30 mL/min carbon dioxide flow rate, resulting in a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of approximately 15000 ml g⁻¹ h⁻¹. Atmospheric conditions were used for the tests. For 30 min before each experiment, 50 mL/min of hydrogen was used to activate the catalyst particles in the reaction at T=700°C. A thermocouple on top of the catalyst bed was used to control the temperature of the reaction. An online gas chromatography (GC112A) with argon as the carrier gas and a TCD (4 mm stainless steel packed column: Porapak Q, 2 m in length) was utilized to analyze the outlet gas stream. A one-hour response time was used for all of the catalytic activity tests. The experimental setup figure is displayed in Fig. 1 . The conversion of reactants (X) and the H2 yield of products (Y) were calculated by the following equations [51]. As can be seen, all samples showed the characteristic peaks of mullite ceramics [53]. It should be noted that the presence of both nickel and cobalt oxides resulted in overlapping XRD patterns; however, all of the bimetallic catalysts followed the same patterns. It was found that both Co3O4 and CoAl2O4 have a cubic structure and essentially identical XRD patterns, and peaks at 2θ=31°, 36.90°, 44.88°, 59.45°, and 65.34° were common for both of them. These cobalt aluminate species might be formed by diffusion of Co+2 into the support [54,55]; however, the existence of the peaks at 2θ=44.88° (400) and 2θ=55.8° (422) were related to the presence of Co3O4 [55–58]. Generally, NiO peaks appeared at 2θ=37.33°, 43.56°, 63.02°, and 75.59° and what's more, the peak at 2θ=36.80° was evidence for the formation of NiAl2O4. The production of NiAl2O4 demonstrated a significant connection between Ni and support, which originated from small Ni crystallites, resulting in more resistance toward the formation of carbon and sintering metal active particles [55,59,60]. It was clearly observed that the peak intensities for all promoted samples at 2θ=44.88° (400) were higher than 20%Ni/mullite, indicating that the presence of cobalt could reduce the particle size of active metal along with well distribution of metal particles. The crystal sizes of support, mono, and bimetal catalysts were obtained by the Scherrer equation and the results were summarized in Table 1 . (9) K λ β cos ( θ ) Where τ is the mean size of the ordered (crystalline) domains, which may be smaller or equal to the particle size, K is a dimensionless shape factor with a value close to unity. The shape factor has a typical value of about 0.9, λ is the X-ray wavelength, β is the line broadening at half the maximum intensity (FWHM), and θ is the Bragg angle. According to Table 1, by reducing the amount of cobalt to 13.5 wt.% and 6.55 wt.%, the size of the NiO particles increased to 46.6 and 57.9, respectively. Remarkably, the particle size of the NiO decreased to 28.1 when the amount of Co was 10 wt.%, indicating the important role of the Co/Ni ratio in the prepared materials. Furthermore, the crystal size of 20%Co/mullite (53.7 nm, θ = 44.9) was larger than 20%Ni/mullite. 3.1.2 Dynamic light scattering studies (DLS) The average mullite particle size before and after sonication was calculated using the DLS technique (Fig. 3 ). The particle size distribution of support before and after sonicated was 855.9 nm and 298.3 nm, respectively, indicating that the sonication process had a positive effect on the preparation of catalysts. 3.1.3 FESEM analysis The morphology and structural properties of prepared materials were investigated using FESEM analysis (Fig. 4 ). It was observed that the addition of Ni and Co had no negative effect on the morphology of mullite ceramics support and its structure was retained during the synthesis of materials without agglomeration of metal particles. Moreover, more porous and smaller particles were observed for 20%Ni/mullite (Fig. 4c, d) catalyst than 20%Co/mullite (Fig. 4g, h) which is in good accordance with the results obtained by XRD analysis. 3.1.4 Dot-mapping and EDS analysis Figs. 5 and 6 displays dot-mapping and EDS images of Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts, respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 5, Ni and Co were uniformly distributed throughout the prepared catalyst, achieving homogenous and uniform dispersion of the Ni and Co components. In addition, EDS analysis confirmed the presence of Ni and Co on the mullite support (Fig. 6). The findings from the XRD experiment were entirely in agreement with the observation that the bimetallic particles did not undergo particle growth and agglomeration. 3.1.5 H2-TPR- analysis To determine the reducibility of the catalyst, the H2-TPR analysis was employed (Fig. 7 ). According to the profile of 20%Co/mullite, two peaks in the range of 300-500°C were distinguished. It showed that two stages were involved in the reduction of cobalt oxide (Co3O4). First, the CoO was created due to Co3O4 reduction (350 °C), and then, the cobalt oxide (CoO) was converted into cobalt metal (480 °C) [61,62]. There were three main reduction peaks for 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite and 20%Ni/mullite catalysts, these peaks were almost similar, but they were slightly different in terms of location and the zone of reduction peak. For 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite, the first peak at 430°C was contributed to the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+, and the second peak at wide range of 500−650°C corresponded to the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 [63]. The peak at 310 °C can be attributed to NiO species which is interacted differently with the support material (a) highly dispersed and interacting with the support, or (b) present as large bulk NiO deposits [64]. The reduction peaks temperature of the bimetallic catalyst were located at slightly higher temperatures compared with two monometallic catalysts due to the interaction between the Ni active component and the support and the formation of NiAl2O4 confirmed by XRD analysis, which is advantageous for the catalyst's anti-sintering and coke formation capacity [65]. There is some indication of a high temperature reduction peak above 700 °C for 20%Co/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite, which may indicate the presence of CoAl2O4 [64]. Ni containing catalyst exhibited a peak at 870°C, corresponding to NiAl2O4 spinel phase [66,67]. 3.1.6 H2-TPD analysis The H2-TPD was performed to evaluate Ni and Ni-Co dispersion of 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalysts (Fig. 8 ). This was accomplished by comparing the actual amounts of H2 adsorbed on the active sites to the ideal amounts. The quantity of dispersed active sites on 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalysts were 5.39% and 24.94%, indicating better dispersed active sites on 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalyst and the key role of the promoter (CO) to this phenomena. This observation was in line with other analyses, such as N2 adsorption/desorption, TEM, FESEM, and XRD. In this line, the turnover frequency of 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalysts towards the conversion of CH4 was also estimated at 800°C which were 1.7 s−1 and 0.45 s−1, respectively. This observation revealed that a bimetallic catalyst had smaller and well dispersion of nano particles which are prominent factors for catalytic applications [68,69]. 3.1.7 BET analysis Fig. 9 (a) and (b) depicted N2 adsorption-desorption and pore size distribution of the 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalysts, respectively. According to the IUPAC classification, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for samples are type IV isotherms with hysteresis loop in meso- and macropores range, demonstrating that the presence of Co particles as a promoter on the support did not significantly alter the pore shapes and porosity of 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite [49]. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the pore size distribution of 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalyst was similar to that of 20%Ni/mullite. The specific surface area, average pore diameter, and pore volume of 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite are shown in Table 2 . As expected, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite had a lower surface area than 20%Ni/mullite, probably due to the larger size of Co than Ni. It is noteworthy that 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite possessed higher surface area than two other bimetallic catalysts, 13.5%Ni-6.5%Co/mullite and 6.5%Ni-13.5%Co/mullite, which indicated well distribution of nanoparticles in the molar ratios 1:1 for Ni and Co (Table 2). 3.1.8 TEM Fig. 10 illustrates the TEM micrographs of 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite. It was observed that there was no considerable sintering or agglomeration of active phase particles. This is in good agreement with the findings of the XRD tests. 3.2 Catalysts activity in the BR process 3.2.1 CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion, and H2 yield Initially, the catalysts were evaluated through a series of tests for biogas reforming methane at temperatures ranging from 650 to 800°C. As can be seen from Fig. 11 a–c, CH4 and CO2 conversions, as well as H2 yield enhanced with increasing reaction temperature, which can be attributed to the endothermic nature of BR, resulting in obtaining better results favoring at high-temperature [70]. It was observed that when the Ni content was increased from 10 wt.% to 20 wt.%, the activity of the catalyst was dropped, probably due to the agglomeration and reduced dispersion of nickel on the surface of the catalyst [71]. In addition, monometallic catalyst (20%Ni/mullite) showed inferior activity than bimetallic catalysts (10%Ni-10%Co/mullite, 6.5%Ni-13.5%Co/mullite, and 13.5%Ni-6.5%Co/mullite), demonstrating the promising synergetic effect of Ni and Co and well dispersion of Ni on the catalyst surface thanks to the presence of Co. When nickel is mixed with other metals, the surface properties can be easily changed to make the catalytic performance better. This is called the synergistic effect [72,73]. To generate bimetallic Ni-based catalysts, one effective and practicable technique is to incorporate a second metal. It has been demonstrated that the carbon resistance of the catalyst can be greatly improved through the synergistic impact of Ni and the second metal [73]. As a result of the strong Co-O interaction, the presence of Co improves the adsorption of CO2, which in turn helps to reduce carbon deposition and high stability [73]. CH4 conversion for 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite, 6.5%Ni-13.5%Co/mullite, and 13.5%Ni-6.5%Co/mullite were 93.49%, 93.22%, and 94.16% at 800°C, respectively. Although these catalysts had almost 94% CH4 conversion at 800°C, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite and 6.5%Ni-13.5%Co/mullite showed higher CH4 conversion at 650-750°C than others. Regarding H2 production yield, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite and 6.5%Ni-13.5%Co/mullite demonstrated higher activity (Fig. 11c). As a result, the catalytic performance of a bimetallic catalyst exhibited a superior activity trend to that of monometallic catalysts [74]. The inactivity of cobalt monometallic catalyst is due to the activation of the C-H bond, which is the only important step in the BR reaction from a kinetic point of view. As cobalt is an active metal for C-H activation, and as some theoretical studies have shown that metals of group 9 (such as cobalt) are expected to be slightly more active than later transition metals [75,76], the low activity detected for the cobalt catalysts should be the result of a rapid deactivation process, such as the deposition of carbon and/or surface oxidation of the cobalt particles. Consequently, the simultaneous presence of cobalt and nickel in the bimetallic catalyst should alter their physical-chemical state, thereby enhancing the activity and stability of the active sites [76]. All in all, as it is obvious, bimetallic catalysts perform better; this is due to the synergistic effect of two metals on each other. Although 6.5%Ni-13.5%Co/mullite had better activity, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite was the optimized catalyst because, by less consumption of Co as the second metal and promoter, the results were almost the same. 3.2.2 Time on stream of 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite As previously discussed, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite showed higher activity at T=800°C in comparison with other catalysts. Fig. 12 depicts the performance of the catalyst, which was evaluated for 34 h at T=800°C in biogas reforming. Fig. 12(a)–(d) show the CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion, H2 yield, and H2/CO of the optimum catalyst, respectively. Catalyst performance decreased in 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite sample due to coke deposition during long time reaction. This reduction is about 5.45%, 6%, 18.95%, and 0.05% for CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion, H2 yield, and H2/CO, respectively. In addition, the H2/CO ratio is depicted in Fig. 12(d). This ratio has values that are close to 1 in the bimetallic sample. The H2/CO reduction ratio is 0.04% which indicates the fact that the catalyst stability is high. Besides, the H2/CO results showed there is no reverse water gas shift reaction occurred. Generally, the reduction in particle size of active sites leads to increased activity in the BR reaction. As mentioned above, Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts are widely used for the conversion of BR to syngas. The present contribution quantitatively compares its findings to those of previous investigations in Table 3 . It should be noted that the comparison is implemented in terms of CH4 conversion. As presented, Al2O3-supported catalyst do not provide very good activity in the CH4 conversion. However, Al2O3-ZrO2, SiO2, ZSM5, and halloysite supported catalysts provide considerable conversions. The obtained results of this study revealed that Ni-Co/mullite catalyst was a privileged catalyst for the biogas reforming reaction. 3.3 Spent catalysts characterization results 3.3.1 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of spent catalysts in BR reaction are illustrated in Fig. 13 . The mechanism of the synergistic influence of Ni-Co alloy on catalytic performance is studied by analyzing the XRD spectra of the spent catalysts. Ni species would have re-oxidized during the reaction. However, the other spent catalysts display reflections at 2θ=44.6° and 51.3°, corresponding to Ni (111), (200) [78]. The intensity of CoAl2O4 peaks in Co containing samples was decreased due to carbon deposition. Furthermore, at around 2θ=27°, the coke deposition on bimetal catalysts is observed. According to Table 4 , the crystal size of Ni slightly increased in 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite spent catalyst in comparison with 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite fresh catalyst, which is demonstrated that the catalyst was sintered [79]. 3.3.2 FESEM analysis Fig. 14 illustrates the SEM images of 20%Ni/mullite and 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite. It can be seen that 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalyst had a smaller amount of coke deposition and a less sintered active site than 20%Ni/mullite. This observation was in good accordance with obtained results from the biogas reforming reaction in which the bimetallic catalyst showed better performance. 3.3.3 BET analysis Fig. 15 (a) and (b) depict N2 adsorption-desorption and pore size distribution, respectively. Although both samples followed the same pattern, slight pore blocking phenomena occurred for the spent catalyst during the reaction. Therefore, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalyst has reasonably good thermal stability and suitable coke resistance in the process of BMR. Besides, the BET surface area of 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite before and after the reaction at 800°C is shown in Table 4. The 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite BET surface area was reduced after BR reaction. 3.3.4 TEM analysis Fig. 16(a) illustrates the TEM image of the spent 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalyst. As can be seen the spent catalyst suffered from the aggregation and carbon deposition during the catalytic process. 3.3.5 TGA analysis In the next stage, to evaluate the thermal stability and amount of coke deposited on the 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite catalyst, TGA analysis was performed (Fig. 16 (b)). As can be seen, only 6 wt.% weight loss for 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite was observed around 530 °C which was related to the production of less active Cβ species in the mixed form of amorphous and filamentous carbon. Since the carbon deposition was very low, the oxidation of the reduced metal could be considered as another factor for catalyst deactivation [80–82]. A slight amount of Cγ species (probably graphite) was observed on the spent catalysts in the range temperature of 630-900°C. 4 Conclusion In summary, for the first time, we employed mullite ceramics as appropriate support for the immobilization of Ni/Co. The synthesized mono and bimetallic catalysts were evaluated in biogas methane reforming reaction at temperatures ranging from 650 to 800°C, with a CH4/CO2 ratio of 1 and GHSV equal to 15,000 ml g⁻¹ h⁻¹. Among all synthesized catalysts, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullites showed higher CH4 and CO2 conversions as well as H2 yield at T=800°C thanks to the synergy effect of Ni-Co alloy in BR. According to findings, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite was better catalyst in terms of H2 yield and lower coke deposition. Altogether, we speculate that the mullite ceramics can be effectively employed as a support for the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts with high stability and performance. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane, in which harmful greenhouse gases convert to syngas, is one of the most important approaches to reducing concerns about global warming and increasing greenhouse gases. It was well found that support has a key role in the catalytic performance of heterogeneous catalysts in all aspects of chemistry. In this study, the effect of mullite(3Al2O3·2SiO2) ceramics as a support for the immobilization of Ni and Co to prepare bimetallic catalyst was explored in dry reforming of methane (DRM) at a temperature range of 650–800°C and gas hour space velocity (GHSV) equal to 15000 ml g⁻¹ h⁻¹. To evaluate the synergetic effect of the Ni-Co alloy, the diverse range of Ni/Co mass ratios (1:0, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 0:1) were prepared via the co-impregnation method. The synthesized materials were characterized through X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption/desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), dot mapping analysis, Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS), Dynamic light scattering (DLS), temperature-programmed reduction analysis (H2-TPR), H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Based on findings, the mullite support has the high potential to act as appropriate support to immobilize metal particles with good distribution, which is beneficial for BR, especially in terms of coke and sintering resistivity. Among synthesized catalysts, 10%Ni-10%Co/mullite showed the highest CH4, CO2 conversions, and H2 yield at 800°C.
coredata.dc:title: Co-Ni bimetallic supported on mullite as a promising catalyst for biogas dry reforming toward hydrogen production
